title: Black Butte (Siskiyou County, California)
text:
Black Butte (formerly Wintoon Butte, Cone Mountain, Sugar Loaf and Muir's Peak) is a cluster of overlapping <a href="dacite">dacite</a> <a href="lava%20dome">lava dome</a>s in a <a href="butte">butte</a>,
a <a href="satellite%20cone">satellite cone</a> of <a href="Mount%20Shasta">Mount Shasta</a>. It is located directly adjacent to the northbound lanes of <a href="Interstate%205">Interstate 5</a> at <a href="List%20of%20exits%20on%20Interstate%205">milepost 742</a> between the city of <a href="Mount%20Shasta%2C%20California">Mount Shasta</a> and <a href="Weed%2C%20California">Weed, California</a>. The highway crosses a pass, Black Butte Summit, at the western base of the lava domes. The lava domes were extruded at the foot of the cone of <a href="Shastina">Shastina</a> following the period of its major eruptions about 9,000–10,000 years ago.
A <a href="United%20States%20Forest%20Service">United States Forest Service</a> <a href="fire%20lookout%20tower">fire lookout tower</a> was built on the summit in the early 1930s, but destroyed during the <a href="Columbus%20Day%20Storm%20of%201962">Columbus Day Storm of 1962</a>. A new lookout was built in 1963 and operated until 1973. The building was moved by helicopter to a new location in 1975 and only the concrete foundation remains today. A trail leads to the summit from a <a href="trailhead">trailhead</a> accessible by <a href="gravel%20road">gravel road</a>s off the Everitt Memorial Highway.
The summit boasts an outstanding view of the southwest side of Shasta and Shastina, and on clear days <a href="Mount%20McLoughlin">Mount McLoughlin</a> is easily visible to the north in Oregon. <a href="Lassen%20Peak">Lassen Peak</a> is visible around to the south.
